flow.context: Regan Trittler is CEO & Founder of PMI Lake of the Ozarks, a PMI franchise in Osage Beach he launched in late 2022 — about three years old and still scaling. He's the final decision-maker and is personally listed as host on Vrbo and Airbnb properties. His ops team includes Candice Reimers (GM) and Chrissy Osteen (Ops & Guest Relations). They run Booking Automation as their PMS and PriceLabs for dynamic pricing, heavily market smart-home tech and photo documentation during inspections, but have no AI or dedicated inspection QA tool. Strongest hook to Sam: Regan's Vrbo listings describe his properties as an 'angler's paradise' with fishing tournament references — Sam founded a fishing club in high school and is an avid fisherman.

opener.label: OPENER — FISHING HOOK
opener.say: Hey Regan — this might be a little random, but I was checking out some of your lake listings and saw the angler's paradise stuff. I'm a big fisherman myself — actually started a fishing club back in high school. Anyway, it's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Feet-up energy. Smile. Let the fishing line breathe before you say the company name. You want him to register 'fisherman' before 'pitch.'

branches.label: "Now's not a good time" / seems rushed

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — PAIN TRIGGER
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well hey, the reason I'm reaching out — I work with a few other vacation rental operators in lake markets, and the thing that keeps coming up is this inspection photo problem. Like, the cleaners are taking photos after every turnover, which is great, but then nobody actually has time to go through all of them. So stuff slips through — a stain on a couch, a scratch on a countertop, a missing set of towels — and by the time anyone catches it, the next guest's already checked in. Now the owner's upset, there's no clean documentation, and the management company ends up eating the cost. Does any of that ring a bell for you guys?
heard_no.note: This is the pain trigger. Slow down on the specific examples — let each one land. PAUSE after 'ring a bell' and let him react. You're painting his day back to him.

branches.label: "We've got that handled" / "We have a process"
"You'd need to talk to someone else on my team"

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone in your shoes. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Genuine curiosity. Let him talk. Whatever he says, bridge into discovery questions. Don't re-pitch what he already knows.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday or Friday?
bad_timing.note: Don't push. Offer specific days. If he gives a callback time, lock it in and note it immediately.

reschedule_confirmed.label: RESCHEDULE LOCKED
reschedule_confirmed.say: Perfect — I'll give you a ring then. Appreciate it, Regan. Talk soon.
reschedule_confirmed.note: Put the callback on your calendar right now. Note the exact day and time he gave you. Set a reminder 5 minutes before.

confused_guard_up.label: GUARD UP — PERMISSION PIVOT
confused_guard_up.say: Yeah totally fair — it is a cold call, I'll be straight with you. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it doesn't sound relevant.
confused_guard_up.note: Disarm with honesty. The 30-second ask lowers the stakes. Smile through it — he can hear it in your voice.

pain_trigger_short.label: 30-SECOND PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger_short.say: So I work with a few vacation rental companies in lake markets — and the thing I keep hearing is their teams are taking hundreds of turnover photos but nobody has time to actually review them all. Stuff gets missed, guests check in, damage shows up after the fact, and the PM company eats it. We built an AI that reviews those photos automatically and flags issues before the next guest walks in. Would you be open to taking a look sometime this week?
pain_trigger_short.note: This is compressed — pain, solution, CTA in 30 seconds. You promised 30, so deliver. PAUSE after the CTA and wait.

branches.label: "Talk to Candice or Chrissy about that"

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION DENIED — SPLIT
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't relevant?
permission_rejected.note: This splits the objection. 'Bad time' reopens the door for a callback. 'Not relevant' is a real no — respect it.

pain_resonates.label: PAIN LANDS — PIVOT TO DISCOVERY
pain_resonates.say: Yeah, I hear that a lot. So I'm curious — what does your inspection process actually look like right now? Are your cleaners the ones taking the photos, or do you have separate inspectors going through after them?
pain_resonates.note: STOP PITCHING. He's warm. Ask questions. Their site says they oversee cleaning AND inspections — find out if those are the same people or different. Listen more than you talk.

branches.label: "We use Booking Automation for most of it"

discovery_deeper.label: DIG INTO THEIR WORKFLOW
discovery_deeper.say: Got it. And when an issue does get caught — like damage or something missing — how does that flow work? Is someone on your team reviewing every single photo set, or is it more of a spot-check thing?
discovery_deeper.note: You're looking for the gap. Their blog literally says 'document everything and take photos during inspections' — they know it matters. The question is whether anyone can actually keep up with reviewing all of it.

branches.label: "Nobody reviews every photo" / admits the gap

discovery_tech_stack.label: TECH STACK CONVERSATION
discovery_tech_stack.say: Oh nice — you're on Booking Automation with PriceLabs, right? Those are solid. So on the ops side — the actual turnover photos and inspection documentation — is that all running through Booking Automation too, or do you have something separate for that piece?
discovery_tech_stack.note: You know their stack from research. Showing homework builds credibility. You're probing for the inspection-specific gap — they almost certainly don't have a dedicated QA layer for photos.

branches.label: "Yeah it's all in Booking Automation" / no separate tool

research_acknowledgment.label: ACKNOWLEDGE HOMEWORK
research_acknowledgment.say: Ha — yeah, I checked out your tech page before I called. I like to know what someone's actually working with before I reach out. Anyway, what I've seen with a lot of folks on Booking Automation is they've got the booking and pricing side dialed, but the inspection QA piece — actually catching issues in the turnover photos — is still mostly manual. That's the gap we fill. Would it make sense to show you what that looks like?
research_acknowledgment.note: Don't be weird about it. Doing homework is a compliment. Bridge quickly to the value prop and CTA.

branches.label: "I don't know if we need that"

discovery_growing_pains.label: STILL FIGURING IT OUT
discovery_growing_pains.say: That's honestly super common, especially a few years in when you're building the portfolio and adding units. How many properties are you guys managing now? I'm just trying to get a sense of scale.
discovery_growing_pains.note: Their unit count isn't public. Get this number — it tells you urgency and sizing. They started in 2022. Competitors in the market run 90 to 125+ units. Don't judge whatever number he gives — just acknowledge and keep going.

branches.label: Shares unit count / keeps opening up

discovery_team_pain.label: TEAM MEMBER OWNS THE WORKFLOW
discovery_team_pain.say: Yeah — and how's that going for them? I ask because the operators I talk to who are reviewing photos from every single turnover — it's just a brutal amount of volume, especially heading into summer. Are they keeping up or is stuff still slipping through the cracks?
discovery_team_pain.note: You know Chrissy is Ops & Guest Relations and Candice is GM. If he mentions either by name, remember it for the referral path. You want him to admit the volume problem even if he says his person is handling it.

branches.label: "You should really talk to them directly"

challenge_gently.label: GENTLY CHALLENGE 'WE'RE FINE'
challenge_gently.say: That's great — honestly, heading into peak season at the lake, having that locked down is huge. Just out of curiosity though — if a cleaner misses something and a guest checks in and finds damage, how do you handle the documentation side? Like proving what was there before versus after the stay?
challenge_gently.note: Don't argue with 'we're fine.' Ask a question that exposes the gap naturally. Before-and-after proof is almost always the weak spot. If he has a genuinely solid answer, respect it.

branches.label: Has a solid answer / truly handled

one_sentence_solution.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
one_sentence_solution.say: So that's exactly what we built. RapidEye plugs into the turnover photos your team's already taking and uses AI to flag damage, missing items, staging issues — automatically. No workflow change on your end, your cleaners keep doing what they're doing, but now every single photo set actually gets reviewed. We're working with a few PM companies managing anywhere from a couple hundred to six hundred-plus units, and it's catching stuff their teams were missing every week.
one_sentence_solution.note: One breath. Say it and stop. The traction is real — NYC luxury (200 homes), East Coast (600 properties), Dubai (~100). Don't list all of them — just let the range land. Go straight to CTA.

branches.label: "We don't take that many photos" / skeptical

reframe_photo_volume.label: REFRAME PHOTO VOLUME
reframe_photo_volume.say: Yeah — and honestly, even if it's 20 or 30 photos per turnover, across a full summer at the lake that adds up fast. But the real value isn't just volume — it's that one photo your team took of a clean-looking kitchen that actually had a crack in the countertop nobody noticed. That's the thing that costs you two grand when the owner finds it three weeks later. Would it be worth 20 minutes to see how it works?
reframe_photo_volume.note: Their own blog advocates documenting everything with photos during inspections. They have photo volume — they may just not realize how fast it compounds across units and turnovers in peak season.

deflect_to_meeting.label: PRICING QUESTION — REDIRECT
deflect_to_meeting.say: Yeah — it honestly depends on the setup and how many units you're running. The easiest thing would be for me to show you what it looks like and we can talk numbers if it makes sense. Would you be open to 20 minutes this week?
deflect_to_meeting.note: Never quote pricing on a cold call. Redirect to the meeting. Asking about price is actually a buying signal — he's interested enough to care what it costs.

cta_meeting.label: CALL TO ACTION
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to taking a look sometime this week? Not a big production — just 20 minutes, I'll walk you through what it actually does, and if it's not a fit we part as friends.
cta_meeting.note: Low pressure. 'Part as friends' takes the edge off. PAUSE and let him answer. Don't keep talking past the ask.

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it. Honestly, I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody on my team cold calls you again — is it that this isn't really a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate getting cold calls?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first — surprise him. Then split. If it's 'I hate cold calls,' the problem IS there, he just hates the delivery. If it's 'not focused on it,' you can explore timing.

branches.label: "I just hate cold calls" / it's the approach
"We really don't need it" / firm no

not_priority_now.label: NOT A PRIORITY RIGHT NOW
not_priority_now.say: Totally fair. Out of curiosity — is it that you're heads down getting ready for peak season, or is it more that the inspection side just hasn't been a big enough pain point yet?
not_priority_now.note: You're probing for timing. Lake of the Ozarks peak season is summer — if he's prepping, RapidEye could help before volume spikes. If 'not painful enough,' the challenge_gently approach or a competitive story might shift it.

branches.label: "Focused on season prep / growth / something else"
Firm no / wants to end the call

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with a PMI franchise you've gotta have something in place. Just curious — is it that you're fully dialed and happy with how it's working, or is it more that switching anything right now would just be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: Acknowledge the franchise structure. Split: 'happy with it' vs. 'switching is hard' are totally different doors. If it's inertia, RapidEye layers on top without replacing anything.

no_switch_needed.label: NO SWITCHING REQUIRED
no_switch_needed.say: Totally — and honestly that's the thing — this doesn't replace anything you're running. It just layers on top. Your cleaners keep taking photos the exact same way, and RapidEye reviews them in the background. No new app for your team, no workflow change. That's actually why most of the companies we work with tried it in the first place — zero lift on their end. Would it be worth a quick look just to see if it fits?
no_switch_needed.note: This is key for a franchise operator — Regan doesn't want to disrupt what's working or mess with anything PMI corporate has set up. RapidEye adds, it doesn't replace.

objection_no_time.label: OBJECTION — NO TIME / NO BUDGET
objection_no_time.say: Totally get it — especially running a franchise, every dollar and every hour's gotta justify itself. Just so I'm not wasting your time — is it more that budget right now is completely tapped, or is it that anything new would have to go through a whole approval thing?
objection_no_time.note: PMI is a franchise but independently owned — Regan likely IS the final approver. If budget is tight, sell the test drive. If there's a process, find out what it looks like.

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Look, you're probably not buying anything right now, and I totally respect that. But when budget opens up — or when peak season hits and the turnover volume spikes — the people who already know what's out there are the ones who move fast. Would you be open to just seeing what it looks like? If nothing else, I can walk you through what a few other lake market PMs are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
sell_test_drive.note: The 'peak season' reference is real — Lake of the Ozarks gets slammed May through September. Turnovers spike, problems spike. This is the value play — competitive intel for free. The meeting is worth his time even if he never buys.

offer_value_anyway.label: OFFER VALUE — EVEN IF NOT BUYING
offer_value_anyway.say: Totally respect that. Hey, if nothing else — I've been talking to a bunch of PM companies in lake markets about what's working for them operationally, especially heading into summer. Would it be worth a quick conversation just to trade notes? No pitch, just what I'm seeing out there.
offer_value_anyway.note: Pure value offer. Zero pressure. This works well with founder-CEOs who are curious and competitive but not in buying mode. If he says no, pivot to referral.

referral_redirect.label: THEY REDIRECT TO SOMEONE ELSE
referral_redirect.say: Oh totally — who on your team would be the right person for this? Would that be Candice or Chrissy?
referral_redirect.note: Drop the names you know — Candice Reimers (GM) and Chrissy Osteen (Ops & Guest Relations). If he confirms one, ask for the best way to reach them. Getting a name from the CEO is basically an internal referral.

referral_get_details.label: GET REFERRAL CONTACT INFO
referral_get_details.say: Perfect. What's the best way to reach them — should I call directly or shoot them an email first? And hey, would you mind giving them a heads up that I'll be reaching out? That way it doesn't land totally cold on their end.
referral_get_details.note: Ask for the warm intro. Even 'I'll mention it' changes how the next call goes. You already have Candice's number (573-280-3696) and Chrissy's (573-286-6764) from research — but getting his blessing to call is what matters.

branches.label: Gives contact info / agrees to mention you
"Just call the main line" / less specific

referral_push_for_name.label: PUSH FOR A SPECIFIC NAME
referral_push_for_name.say: Yeah — if I can get a specific name I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands and doesn't just sit in a generic inbox. Who on your team would own something like turnover quality or inspection operations?
referral_push_for_name.note: Generic inboxes are where outreach goes to die. Push for a name. You know Candice is GM and Chrissy is Ops — if he won't volunteer, you could suggest one.

branches.label: Won't give a name / insists on generic

referral_confirmed.label: REFERRAL LOCKED
referral_confirmed.say: Really appreciate that, Regan. I'll reach out to them this week. And hey — if the fishing out there is as good as your listings make it sound, I might have to make a trip to the lake one of these days.
referral_confirmed.note: End warm. Bring it back to the fishing hook. Leave a great impression — he might mention you to his team even without being asked. Note the referral name, number, and any context in your CRM immediately.

referral_ask.label: ASK FOR A REFERRAL
referral_ask.say: Totally understand. Hey, one last thing — who on your team typically owns the inspection and turnover quality side of things? I just want to make sure if I follow up, I'm reaching out to the right person and not wasting anyone's time.
referral_ask.note: You know it's likely Candice (GM) or Chrissy (Ops & Guest Relations). If he gives a name, that's your next call. If he says 'that's me' — try one more soft CTA.

branches.label: "I don't want to give that out" / declines

last_chance_cta.label: LAST CHANCE CTA
last_chance_cta.say: Got it — well look, if anything changes or if peak season starts bringing more turnover headaches, I'm super easy to find. Would it be cool if I sent you a quick email with some info? That way you've got it if it ever becomes relevant.
last_chance_cta.note: Just get permission to email. An email keeps the door open. If he says yes, send it within the hour.

objection_send_email.label: "SEND ME AN EMAIL"
objection_send_email.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do — what would be most useful to include so it's not just another generic pitch sitting in your inbox? Like, is it more about how it works technically, or what the ROI looks like for a company your size?
objection_send_email.note: Get intel to tailor the email. Whatever he says, build the email around it. Include a specific meeting time suggestion in the email: 'Would Thursday at 2 work for a quick look?' Send within one hour of hanging up.

email_confirmed.label: EMAIL SEND-OFF
email_confirmed.say: Perfect — I'll get that over to you today. I'll keep it short and actually useful. Appreciate your time, Regan.
email_confirmed.note: Send within the hour. Subject line should be personal — reference fishing or the lake, not 'AI inspection platform.' Include one specific time suggestion for a call. Follow up in 3 business days if no reply. His email: regan.trittler@pmilakeoftheozarks.com.

booking_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING NOW
booking_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got my calendar pulled up — how does later this week look? I could do Thursday afternoon or Friday morning. What works better on your end?
booking_meeting.note: Give TWO specific options. Don't say 'whenever works.' Lock the day first, then narrow the time. Send the invite while you're still on the phone if possible.

branches.label: "I'll have to check and get back to you"

meeting_next_week.label: NEXT WEEK — PIN IT DOWN
meeting_next_week.say: Next week works great. How about Tuesday or Wednesday? I'm flexible on morning or afternoon — what's your lighter day?
meeting_next_week.note: Don't let it stay vague. Get a specific day and a time range. Then confirm the exact time and send the invite.

pin_down_meeting.label: PIN IT DOWN — SEND THE INVITE
pin_down_meeting.say: Tell you what — I'll shoot you a quick invite for Wednesday at 2. If that doesn't work, just let me know and we'll move it. That way it's on the books and we're not playing email tag. Sound good?
pin_down_meeting.note: Put the invite on HIS calendar. It's way easier to move a meeting than to schedule one from scratch. If he accepts, it'll stick. Use regan.trittler@pmilakeoftheozarks.com for the invite.

branches.label: Pushes back / won't commit to anything

meeting_booked.label: MEETING CONFIRMED
meeting_booked.say: Perfect — you'll see the invite in just a sec. Really appreciate you taking my call, Regan. And seriously — if you ever need a fishing buddy out at the lake, you know who to call.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. You got the meeting. End warm, end human. Send the calendar invite the second you hang up. Don't add anything else — you won.

graceful_exit.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand. Hey, if anything changes I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Regan. Tight lines.
graceful_exit.note: 'Tight lines' is a fishing blessing — it'll land with a lake market guy. Don't burn the bridge. Log the outcome in your CRM and set a callback reminder for 60-90 days out.
